document.docTitle: Molecular data and morphological characters clarify the taxonomic status of Pintara heringi pieridoides (Liu & Gu, 1994) (Hesperiidae, Pyrginae)

emphasis.docTitle:
Molecular data and morphological characters clarify the taxonomic status of
Pintara heringi pieridoides (Liu & Gu, 1994)
( Hesperiidae , Pyrginae)

subSection.paragraph:
We found
Albiphasma heringi (Mell, 1922)
and
A. pieridoides (Liu & Gu, 1994)
to be conspecific by the 658 bp COI gene sequences and male genitalia characters. Considering the distinguishable wing patterns and allopatric distribution of the two taxa, we treat
pieridoides
as a subspecies of
heringi
. Therefore, the genus
Albiphasma Huang, Chiba, Wang and Fan, 2016
, which was established for
heringi
and
pieridoides
, becomes monotypic, and in light of morphological similarities and close genetic distance between
heringi
and
Pintara bowringi (Joicey & Talbot, 1921)
, we propose its synonymy with
Pintara Evans, 1932
. The adults and male genitalia of both
P. heringi heringi (Mell, 1922)
and
P. heringi pieridoides (Liu & Gu, 1994)
are illustrated.

Key words: skippers , COI , genitalia ,
Albiphasma
, synonymy , subspecies , distribution

Abraximorpha pieridoides Liu & Gu, 1994
was described as a new species based on one male specimen from Hainan ( Chou 1994: 773 , 707, fig. 1). However, without any explanation, Chiba (2008) treated it as a synonym of
A. heringi Mell, 1922
. Likewise, Devyatkin (2012) pointed out that
pieridoides
‘seems likely to represent an extreme (black pattern reduced) variation’ of
heringi
. By elucidating several differences in both wing patterns and male genitalia of the two taxa,
Huang et al . (2016)
tentatively retained the specific status of
pieridoides
although they examined no more materials of the taxon except for the holotype . They also established a new genus, viz.
Albiphasma Huang, Chiba, Wang & Fan, 2016
, for
heringi
and
pieridoides
based on morphological comparison and their unpublished molecular evidence, indicating that
Albiphasma
is closely related to
Pintara Evans, 1932
rather than
Abraximorpha Elwes & Edwards, 1897
.
Shen et al . (2022)
confirmed the validity of
Albiphasma
and its sister group relationship with
Pintara
by a molecular analysis including
P. bowringi (Joicey & Talbot, 1921)
,
P. pinwilli (Butler, 1879)
and
pieridoides
, while
Zhang et al . (2022)
considered this small genus as a subgenus of
Pintara
because they found that the COI barcode difference between
heringi
and
pinwilli
was 6.5% (43 bp).

The purpose of the present paper is to clarify the following questions: Is
pieridoides
a distinct species/subspecies or a synonym of
heringi
? Should
Albiphasma
be treated as a separate genus or merged into
Pintara
?

Specimens examined in this study ( Table 1 ) are deposited in Zhengzhou University of Light Industry (Zhengzhou, Henan , China ). One leg from each specimen was used to extract genomic DNA by using DNeasy® Blood and Tissue Kit (Qiagen, Germany ). Partial COI sequences (658 bp) were amplified with the forward primer LepF (5'-ATTCAACCAATCATAAAGATATTGG-3') and reverse primer LepR (5'- TAAACTTCTGGATGTCCAAAAAATCA-3') (
Hajibabaei et al . 2006
). PCR procedure followed
Hebert et al . (2003)
, and the products were sequenced by Shanghai Sangon Biotechnology Co. Ltd. ( China ). All raw sequences were initially run for a BLAST in NCBI to ensure the creditability. All new sequences were deposited in GenBank ( Table 1 ). Five sequences were downloaded from GenBank for phylogenetic reconstruction ( Table 2 ).

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. Data for the sequenced specimens in this study.

subSection.paragraph: The Comstock-Needham venation system is used in this paper. The terminology of genitalia mainly follows Klots (1970) .

caption.paragraph: TABLE 2. Data for the sequences downloaded from GenBank for phylogenetic reconstruction.

tr.td: Vietnam: Lam Dong, Bao Lam Dambri

caption.paragraph: TABLE 3. Uncorrected pairwise genetic distances (Kimura-2-parameter) for the COI sequences analyzed in this study.

subSection.paragraph:
Molecular analysis. All five samples successfully generated a 658 bp partial COI sequence via PCR and sequencing. Pairwise distance based on the DNA barcode ( Table 3 ) shows that
pieridoides
(B44) and
heringi
(B50, B63) belong to the same species, thus the genus
Albiphasma
is monotypic. In the NJ tree ( Fig. 1 ), the between-group mean distance of clade A and clade B is 7.0%, the Kimura-2-Parameter genetic distance between the samples of the two clades is 6.6%~7.1% ( Table 3 ); the between-group mean distance of clade C, D, E, F and G is 11.4%, and the Kimura-2-Parameter genetic distance between these five clades is 10.1%~12.4% ( Table 4 ). Therefore, clade A and clade B should be treated as one genus, i.e.
Pintara
(=
Albiphasma
syn. nov.
).

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 1. NJ tree based on Kimura-2-Parameter distances for the partial mitochondrial COI sequences, values at nodes represent the bootstrap support (BP) values.
TABLE 4. Uncorrected pairwise genetic distances (Kimura-2-parameter) for the main clades in the NJ tree of this study.

bibRefCitation.author: Evans, W. H.
bibRefCitation.refString: Evans, W. H. (1932) The identification of Indian butterflies (Second edition revised). The Bombay Natural History Society, Madras, 419 pp.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The authors of the genus
Albiphasma
compared the venation of
heringi
with that of
Abraximorpha dividii
in order to prove the two taxa belong to different genera. However, they did not take any members of
Pintara
into the comparison of venation, although the close relationship of
Albiphasma
and
Pintara
had been indicated by both morphological similarities and molecular evidence (
Huang et al . 2016: 148
). Actually, it can be observed from their paper that the venation of
pinwilli
(
Huang et al . 2016: 149
, fig. 12) is same as that of
heringi
(
Huang et al . 2016: 152
, fig. 32). Moreover, the hair tuft on the hind tibiae (
Huang et al . 2016: 149
, fig. 13, 15) and the male genitalia (
Huang et al . 2016: 148
; 150, figs. 16–20; 151, figs. 27–31) of
pinwilli
and
heringi
resemble one another. Therefore, considering the results of molecular analysis and morphological comparison, we propose
Albiphasma
to be a synonym of
Pintara
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2. Adults of
Pintara heringi (Mell, 1922)
. A.

from Hainan (Specimen ID B44, Genitalia No. DLS6). B.

from southern Jiangxi (Specimen ID B63, Genitalia No. JX119). C.
ssp. heringi
from northern Guangdong (Specimen ID B50). Scale bar = 1 cm.

FIGURE 3. Male genitalia of
Pintara heringi pieridoides (Liu & Gu, 1994)
from Hainan (Specimen ID B44, Genitalia No. DLS6). A. genital capsule, dorsal view. B. ditto , ventral view. C. ditto , lateral view. D. uncus and tegumen, dorsal view. E. ring, lateral view. F. uncus and gnathos, ventral view. G. ditto , posterior view. H. left valva, dorsal view. I. juxta. J. aedeagus, left side. K. ditto , dorsal view. L. ditto , right side. M. distal part of aedeagus, left side, enlarged.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Abraximorpha pieridoides Liu & Gu, 1994
, In
Chou 1994: 773
, 707, fig. 1. Type locality: Hainan , China ;
Gu & Chen 1997: 305
;
Yuan et al . 2015: 182
.

Albiphasma pieridoides
:
Huang et al . 2016: 151
;
Wu & Hsu 2017: 1329
.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The taxon
pieridoides
is rather rare in nature. Until now, the holotype was the only known male specimen, of which hand drawings of the male genitalia were provided in the original description ( Chou 1994: 773 , fig. 84) and in
Huang et al . (2016: 153
, fig. 34). Here we illustrate a second male specimen of
pieridoides
( Fig. 2 : A, Fig. 3 ) and compare its morphological characters to those of
heringi
( Fig. 2 : B, Fig. 2 : C, Fig. 4 ).

Although
pieridoides
and
heringi
are proven to be conspecific by the COI gene sequences, the differences in wing patterns of the two taxa should not be ignored. In both sexes of
pieridoides
( Fig. 2 : A; Chou 1994: 707 , fig. 1 for male; Wu & Hsu 2017: 1331 , fig. 13 for female), the ground color of the wings and the veins of the hind wing are white, while in
heringi
, the ground color and veins of the wings in male ( Fig. 2 : B; Fig. 2 : C;
Huang et al . 2016
: figs. 1–4; Wu & Hsu 2017: 1331 , fig. 11, 12) and female ( Chou 1994: 707 , fig. 2;
Jiang et al . 2001: 132
, fig. 26-445;
Huang et al . 2016
: figs. 5, 6) are dark brown. In
pieridoides
, the forewing is mostly white except for some dark stains, which, in
heringi
, are developed and divide the reduced white stripes into spots of different sizes; the series of elongate subapical spots is more developed in
pieridoides
than in
heringi
. Spots on the hind wing are separated in
pieridoides
but closely arranged in
heringi
.

Differences in male genitalia between the two taxa can be observed as follows: in lateral view, the middle branch at distal valva is slightly longer and bent upward in
pieridoides
, with the ventral margin smooth ( Fig. 3 : C), while in
heringi
, it is shorter, straight, decorated with sawteeth ventrally ( Fig. 4 : C); in lateral view, the distal part of aedeagus is longer in
pieridoides
( Fig. 3 : J); the triangular lobe at left side of distal aedeagus is more developed in
heringi
( Fig. 4 : H).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. Male genitalia of
Pintara heringi heringi (Mell, 1922)
from southern Jiangxi (Specimen ID B63, Genitalia No. JX119). A. genital capsule, dorsal view. B. ditto , ventral view. C. ditto , lateral view. D. ditto , oblique view. E. aedeagus, left side. F. ditto , dorsal view. g. ditto , ventral view. H. distal part of aedeagus, anterior view, enlarged. M. ditto , dorsal view, enlarged.

subSubSection.paragraph:
In addition,
pieridoides
is endemic to Hainan , while
heringi
is known from Guangdong , Jiangxi and Fujian ( Wu & Hsu 2017 ). The record of
heringi
from Hainan by Chou (1994: 707) and
Yuan et al . (2015)
is erroneous and should be rejected. Therefore, here we treat
pieridoides
as a subspecies of
heringi
.

The specimen of ‘ heringi’ from central Vietnam illustrated by Devyatkin (2012 : fig. 1, 2) exhibits a combination of the forewing of
Pintara heringi heringi
and the hind wing of
P. heringi pieridoides
, as pointed out by
Huang et al . (2016: 150)
. The taxonomic status of this form requires further study.

subSection.paragraph: We are grateful to the Wuzhishan Division of Hainan Tropical Rainforest National Park Administration and the Administration of Nanling National Nature Reserve for the permission of field survey. Special thanks are due to Mr. Hu Hualin (Longnan, Jiangxi , China ) for providing specimens.
